titleStmt.title: The Kings Maiesties letter, sent from Holmby to both Houses of Parliament, with his Majesties propositions for some bishops or doctors appointed to attend his Majestie for the exercise of his conscience, and clearing of his judgement in the present differences in religion. With other papers concerning the propositions of the King and the commissioners at Holmby-House. And his Majesties desire to have some of these to be sent to him; viz. The Bishop of London. The Bishop of Salisbury. The Bishop of Peterborough. Dr. Shelden. Dr. May. Dr. Sanderson. Dr. Bayly. Dr. Heywood. Dr. Beale. Dr. Fuller. Dr. Hammond. Dr. Taylor.
titleStmt.author: England and Wales. Sovereign (1625-1649 : Charles I)

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 8 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

titleStmt.title: The Kings Maiesties letter, sent from Holmby to both Houses of Parliament, with his Majesties propositions for some bishops or doctors appointed to attend his Majestie for the exercise of his conscience, and clearing of his judgement in the present differences in religion. With other papers concerning the propositions of the King and the commissioners at Holmby-House. And his Majesties desire to have some of these to be sent to him; viz. The Bishop of London. The Bishop of Salisbury. The Bishop of Peterborough. Dr. Shelden. Dr. May. Dr. Sanderson. Dr. Bayly. Dr. Heywood. Dr. Beale. Dr. Fuller. Dr. Hammond. Dr. Taylor.
titleStmt.author: England and Wales. Sovereign (1625-1649 : Charles I)
C. W.
Smith, W., of Nottingham.

notesStmt.note: Consists of 3 letters: one by Charles I, dated Holmby, Feb. 17. 1646 [i.e. 1647]; one dated and signed: Holmby Feb. 17. C.W.; and one signed and dated: W. Smith. Dated at our quarters at Holmby; this 18. of February 1646 [i.e. 1647].
Annotation on Thomason copy: "feb: 22th 1646"; the 7 in imprint date crossed out.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE KINGS Maie≈øties Letter, Sent from Holmby to both Hou≈øes of PARLIAMENT, With his Maje≈øties Propo≈øitions for ≈øome Bi≈øhops or Doctors appointed to attend his Maje≈øtie for the exerci≈øe of his Con≈øcience, and clearing of his judgement in the pre≈øent differences in Raligion.
With other Papers concerning the Propo≈øitions of the King and the Commi≈øsioners at Holmby-Hou≈øe.
And his Maje≈øties de≈øire to have ≈øome of the≈øe to be ≈øent to him; viz.

div.head: The Copie of a LETTER Sent from the KINGS Maie≈øty at Holmby, to the Speaker of the Hou≈øe of Peeres, pro tempore, to be communicated to both Hou≈øes of PARLIAMENT.
With a Li≈øt of the names of the Bi≈øhops and Doctors propounded by the King to attend his Maje≈øty.
div.p: SInce I have never di≈ø≈øembled, nor hid my con≈øcience. And that I am not yet ≈øatisfied, with the alteration in Religion, to which ye de≈øire my con≈øent;

I will not loo≈øe time in giving rea≈øons, (which are too obvious to every body) why it is fit for me to be attended by ≈øome of
my Chaplains, who≈øe opinions (as Clergymen) I e≈øteeme and reverence.

Not onely for the exerci≈øe of my con≈øcience; but al≈øo for the clearing of my judgement, concerning the pr ‚Ä¢ ≈øent differences in Religion; as I have (at full) declared to Mr. Mar≈øhall, and his Fellow-Mini≈øter: having ≈øhewed them that is the be≈øt and likelie≈øt meanes of giving me ≈øatisfaction (which without it, I cannot have) in the≈øe things; whereby the di≈øtractions of the Church may be the better ≈øetled.

Wherefore I de≈øire, that (at lea≈øt) two of the≈øe reverend Divines, who≈øe names I have here ≈øet downe, may have free liberty to wait upon me, for the di≈øcharging of their duties to me, according to their Function.

postscript.p: For the Speaker of the Hou≈øe of Peers, pro tempore, to be communicated to the two Hou≈øes of Parliament at We≈øtmin≈øter a≈ø≈øembled.

list.item: Dr. Shelden, Clerk of my C ‚Ä¢ o≈øet.

postscript.p: The≈øe or two or more of the≈øe Bi≈øhops and Epi≈øcopali Doctors, his Maje≈øty de≈øires may have free libertie to wait upon him, to officiate for the exerci≈øe of his con≈øcience, and clearing of his con≈øcience.

div.head: The Copie of a Letter from Holmby-Hou≈øe, concerning ≈øome a≈ø≈øaires ≈øince his Maje≈øties and the Comi≈ø≈øioners comming thither.
div.p: BEing come ≈øo neere, I cannot chu≈øe but ki≈ø≈øe your hand with a ≈øalute of my reall affection: I am not ignorant, that as we expect determination from your Orb, ≈øo you re≈øolution from this. I wi≈øh I cou ‚Ä¢ d ≈øatisfie your expectation in letting you under≈øtand what we ≈øo much d ‚Ä¢ ubt, and therefore are the ≈øadder. What I have to communicate (at pre≈øent) as a certainty is this, concerning the King, the Commi≈ø≈øioners, the Mini≈øters, and their endeavours with his Maje≈øty.

1. Concerning the King, his Maje≈øty is very cheerfull and plea≈øant, but much grayer then he was when he went from his Court at White-hall: he is very familiar with the Lords and de≈øires to be as neer London as may be. His Maje≈øty came hither ye≈øter night, all things being ≈øo well prepared, that his Maie≈øty ≈øhewed no di≈ølike at all: he de≈øired Sir Fulk Grivell might be his Cup-bearer, and Mr. Mildmay hath his place by the Kings appointment al≈øo. No Malignants are permitted, nor dare attempt to come to come to his Maje≈øtie, his Maje≈øtie being freed from tho≈øe late fittings up and watchings that he had before, begins now to look better.

2 The Commi≈øsioners are tyred with a long and tedious journey, tyre≈øome wayes, and a carefull charge and would take it for a very great favour, if they might be called home, being very willing to re≈øigne up their places.

3 The Mini≈øters, Mr. Mar≈øhall, and Mr. Carol preached on the Lords Day, but the King will not hear them, His Maje≈øty hath often conference with them, and argues very ≈øtifly for Epi≈øcopacy, and the Book of common prayer, and again≈øt the Covenant, and they endeavour to give his Maje≈øty fatisfaction in every ≈øcruple; one of them ≈øayes grace every day at his Maje≈øties table But his Maje≈øty would faine have ≈øome of his own Chaplains that are not for the Presbyterian way; yet do we not ≈øo de≈øpaire, but that wee hope in good time, his Maie≈øty will bee wrought vpon to joyn with the Parliament, if ill in≈øtruments be ≈øtill kept from him. God grant an happy union. Thus I conclude,

div.head: The Copy of another Letter from Holmby hou≈øe, concerning his Maie≈øties Letter ≈øent by the Commif≈øioners.
div.p:
His Maje≈øty told the Lords, that hee had a Letter to ≈øend to the Parlament, for ≈øome of his own Chaplaines, to have liberty to be with Him; And offered their Lord≈øhips to read the ≈øaid Letter before his Maje≈øty had ≈øealed it, and to ≈øend it to the Parliament. But their Lord≈øhips acquainted his Maje≈øty, that they could not do it ≈øafely by their Jn≈øtructions; but if his Maje≈øty would ≈øeale it up, they would ≈øend it to the Parliament,
which his Maje≈øty did, and gave it to their Lord≈øhips, who have ≈øent it up accordingly, Their Lord≈øhips de≈øiring liberty to come to London, being weary of the pre≈øent imployment. Sir, no more at pre≈øent, but that I ≈øub≈øcribe my ≈øelf,

closer.dateline: Dated at our quarters at Holmby; this 18. of February 1646.
